Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Small: Collaborative Research: Electronic Textiles for Ambulatory Health Monitoring

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Ambulatory health monitoring has been demonstrated to provide significant benefits to patients in a number of studies. The biggest promise for improved results for patients lies in the long-term, ambulatory monitoring of patients with chronic illnesses to help doctors and patients identify health issues before they reach a crisis stage. This project pursues the design of garments for ambulatory health monitoring that have the look and feel of every day clothing, together with an approach to monitoring that removes some of the barriers to patient compliance by automatically annotating physiological data with activities and motions, collecting data only during specific conditions, and having minimal impact on daily routine. The intellectual merits lie in the algorithms, design methodologies, and evaluation methodologies that enable wear-and-forget garments for ambulatory health monitoring. The approach developed by this project uses a computationally intensive pose estimation algorithm that automatically adapts a more computationally efficient algorithm for activity classification. This project addresses the challenges of providing garments that look and feel like everyday clothing by developing design and evaluation methodologies for incorporating fiber-based sensors into garments. These have significant advantages over discrete sensors by being woven or sewn into the fabric, covering much larger areas of a garment, and draping naturally. The broader impacts of the research lie in the potential to remove barriers that prevent the effective use of ambulatory health monitoring to improve the quality of life for patients and their families.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ambulatory health monitoring has been demonstrated to provide significant benefits to patients in a number of studies. The biggest promise for improved results for patients lies in the long-term, ambulatory monitoring of patients with chronic illnesses to help doctors and patients identify health issues before they reach a crisis stage. This project explored the design of garments for ambulatory health monitoring that have the look and feel of every day clothing, together with an approach to monitoring that removes some of the barriers to patient compliance by automatically annotating physiological data with activities and motions, collecting data only during sifonditions, and having minimal impact on daily routine.

The outcomes of this grant include developing a technique for automically classifying activities that is both user-independent (it does not have to be trained on a particular person) and sensor-independent (it can work with sensor types other than the sensors that were used for training the set of known activities). Results of our user study show that the classifer operations twelve times better than chance when using a video-based motion capture system and ten times better than chance when using a loose-fitting garment.  In both cases, the training set was from a video-based motion capture system, illustrating the sensor-independence of the technique, and trained using people other than the subjects in the experiment, showing the user-independence of the technique.  The classifer works for the whole body, and thus can distinguish between fine-grained activies such as brushing teeth and brushing hair, as well as much more coarse-grained activies such as running and walking.  The classifier can report how similar an unknown activity (an activity not in the training set) is to the known activities.  Finally, the classifer works on sequences of a stick figure model of the body, so the stick figure animation of an unknown activity can be viewed at a later time for manual classification. 

The broader impacts of the research lie in the potential to remove barriers that prevent the effective use of ambulatory health monitoring to improve the quality of life for patients and their families. The potential benefits include enabling applications in home health monitoring, particularly for the elderly and people with disabilities, reducing the need for office visits and in-hospital observation stays; and providing students with a highly interdisciplinary research experience that will enhance their potential for making technical innovations in health monitoring and pervasive computing. The benefits of our project are not restricted to ambulatory health monitoring. Robust and detailed activity classification and pose estimation have applications in sports performance, entertainment, and context awareness for pervasive computing. Similarly, robust design and evaluation of fiber-based sensors for garments has application across the field of electronic textiles. Finally, e-textiles have the potential to rejuvenate the textiles and garment industries in the U.S.
